results.brief_description: Taree Mackenzie’s Pepper’s ghost, triangles, cyan and red gives new life to the Victorian-era invention made popular by John Henry Pepper. Pepper’s ghost was an early special effect that projected ghosts onto theatre stages through light and reflection.

constellations_primary.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_primary.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

results.title_for_label: Pepper’s ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red
results.description:
Pepper’s ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red gives new life to the Victorian-era invention made popular by John Henry Pepper. Pepper’s ghost was an early special effect that projected ghosts onto theatre stages through light and reflection.

“Pepper’s ghost has typically been used in theatre, film and amusement park rides. This simple effect uses an angled pane of glass to create the illusion of a ghost-like image within another scene, exploiting the optical properties of glass as both a reflector and transmitter of light.

In my work I wanted to replicate this effect using simple abstract forms and flat fields of colour to draw attention to this merging of the two light images, while also laying bare the apparatus used to create the illusion.” – Taree Mackenzie
description_for_label:
Pepper’s ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red gives new life to the Victorian-era invention made popular by John Henry Pepper. Pepper’s ghost was an early special effect that projected ghosts onto theatre stages through light and reflection.

“Pepper’s ghost has typically been used in theatre, film and amusement park rides. This simple effect uses an angled pane of glass to create the illusion of a ghost-like image within another scene, exploiting the optical properties of glass as both a reflector and transmitter of light.

In my work I wanted to replicate this effect using simple abstract forms and flat fields of colour to draw attention to this merging of the two light images, while also laying bare the apparatus used to create the illusion.” – Taree Mackenzie

results.title: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films.

constellations_primary.name: Voice and the moving image
constellations_primary.description: Sound changed cinema, but it wasn't always welcome, but it hasn't stopped people aspiring for the spotlight.

results.title_for_label: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
results.description:
Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films. Their first film, Those Who Love (1926), was funded by their family and hailed as a “dazzling triumph” by publication Everyone’s.

Influenced by Hollywood melodramas and German Expressionism, the sisters’ films featured emotionally honest characters and broke with traditional gender norms. Fox Films even offered McDonagh and her sisters the chance to make movies in Hollywood, but they decided they “would end up very small fish in a big pond” so stayed in Australia, where they worked up until the mid-1930s.
description_for_label:
Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films. Their first film, Those Who Love (1926), was funded by their family and hailed as a “dazzling triumph” by publication Everyone’s.

Influenced by Hollywood melodramas and German Expressionism, the sisters’ films featured emotionally honest characters and broke with traditional gender norms. Fox Films even offered McDonagh and her sisters the chance to make movies in Hollywood, but they decided they “would end up very small fish in a big pond” so stayed in Australia, where they worked up until the mid-1930s.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You
results.brief_description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949).

constellations_primary.name: Orwell & Snowden
constellations_primary.description: Explores Orwell as a representation of the NSA, and the infamous Snowden leak.

results.description: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949). Transforming the dystopian thriller into a click-and-play game set in our contemporary online world, players are cast as government operatives who trawl social media profiles to uncover terrorists and political dissidents. Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You presents players with moral dilemmas, forcing them to think about their own ethics and beliefs when responding to the game’s reflection of our current society. It also asks them to analyse the effect of surveillance culture on society and the proliferation of false information and fake news.
description_for_label: Safeguard society by spying on your fellow citizens in this game based on the themes of George Orwell’s novel 1984 (1949). Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You presents players with moral dilemmas, forcing them to think about their own ethics and beliefs when responding to the game’s reflection of our current society. It also asks them to analyse the effect of surveillance culture on society and the proliferation of false information and fake news.

results.title: Orchids to You cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Fox Film Corporation and William A. Seiter
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: John Boles Jean Muir “Orchids to You!” He learned about women from her flowers! Not suitable for general exhibition The two sheets of glass are held together using Gunn’s Slide branded tape: Gunn’s Slide, 9 Collins Place Melb. Cent. 2736,
